newsitem.title: USA: FBI offers $500,000 reward for Olympic bomber.
newsitem.headline: FBI offers $500,000 reward for Olympic bomber.

text.p: The Federal Bureau of Investigation on Monday made public the tape recording of a telephone warning of the Olympic Park bombing in Atlanta and offered a reward for information leading to the arrest of the bomber or bombers.
The FBI announced it would pay "up to $500,000" for photographs, videotapes or information that helps catch the person who planted the bomb on July 27 at Centennial Olympic Park.

Announcing the reward at a news conference in Atlanta, FBI deputy director Weldon Kennedy called the bombing, which killed two people and injured more than 100, a "vicious crime" and appealed to the public for help.
"This investigation continues to have our highest priority," Kennedy said.
Agents played a tape of a telephone warning called in before the bomb went off. The brief message said there was a bomb in the park and told authorities they had 30 minutes.

The FBI has said very little about the bombing in the 4-1/2 months since the explosion. Security guard Richard Jewell, who alerted authorities to a knapsack containing the bomb, was initially identified as a suspect but was cleared on Oct. 26.
